product.description: Evening event on this population milestone

product.title: ITASE (tentative date)
product.description: International Trans-Antarctic Scientific Expedition

product.description: 1/9/00 WCRB Bunch in the Skyline room.12-2 pm Tickets are part of a contest on WCRB. Screening of Mysteries of Egypt at 2:00pm. Laura Carlo introduces film

product.title: Science Street Cafe Press Party
product.description: Guests from the media are invited to the Museum's Friday night offering, Science St. Cafe

product.title: Magic Night
product.description: Candy O'Terry from WMJX - Magic 106.7 - will do a live appearance promoting a screening of Mysteries of Egypt for listeners

product.title: Reptiles: Real and Robotic Press Opening
Reptiles: Real and Robotic
product.description: Developed by the San Diego Natural History Museum, this exhibit includes moving, robotic reptiles and realistic looking reptile models. This exhibit explores the evolution, diversity, adaptability, eating habits and means of protection of reptiles. "Reptiles", features amazing robotic reptiles, some up to 10 times actual size. Some of the reptiles are: "Nile Crocodile", 23 ft long - life size. This robot crocodile contains two crocodile babies inside its mouth, illustrating how they transport their babies to safety. "Jackson’s Chameleon", 20 ft long - 10 times actual size, "Alligator Snapping Turtle", 20 ft. long - 10 times actual size. Those are just a few, there are six robot reptiles all together.

product.title: First Friday Lecture (Feb)
product.description: Lizard Islands: Anioles, Curlytails, Geckos, Galliwasps and Iguanas of the Caribbean

product.title: Mix 98.5 Dolphins Sneak Screenings
product.description: Sneak Preview of Omni film Dolphins for lucky winners from WMBX Mix 98.5 FM. 7:00 pm , Thursday, March 9.

product.title: American Express Dolphins Night
product.description: Monday, March 13, 2000 - 6:30 - 8:30 pm American Express and WODS on site in Omni Theater. Screening Dolphins for AmEx customers.

product.title: WHERE Magazine Dolphins Night
product.description: Monday, March 27, 2000.

product.title: Secrets of Aging: National Press Opening
product.description: Developed by a team of experts led by Boston's Museum of Science, "Secrets of Aging" is a landmark exhibit that explores the science behind behind the universal experience of aging. The exhibit debuts in Boston before touring nationally around the country.

product.title: Secrets of Aging
product.description: This will is a 6,000 sq. ft. exhibit being developed (right now) by the Museum of Science. It’s a hands-on exhibit that will explore and explain what science can tell us about the universal experience of aging. Visitors will be able to explore the latest aging research, get involved in inter-generational activities and games, hear and tell stories about growing older and learn what is helpful and what can be harmful as people try to alter the aging process.

product.title: First Friday Lecture (Apr)
product.description: Journeys with the Pink Dolphins of the Amazon

product.title: Star Night - Stargazing
product.description: Friday, April 7, 2000. STaR 93.7 on site

product.title: Magic 106.7 "Healthy Brunch"
product.description: Magic 106.7's Candy O'Terry on site to promote "Secrets of Aging", Sunday, Skyline Brunch, and introduce 2:00pm "Dolphins" in the Mugar Omni Theater.

product.title: Press Screening: Michael Jordan to the Max
JAM'N & Jordan

product.title: Cabot Creamery
product.description: Cabot Creamery in Museum's main lobby to promote Cabot Cheese, health benefits of calcium and pass out fun books. They will be here from noon to 4:00 pm

product.title: American Express Dolphins Night II
product.description: American Express on-site to screen Dolphins to their customers. 7-9pm in the Omni Theater

product.title: T. rex Named Sue Press Opening
T. Rex Sue
product.description: This is a working title, a permanent one is forthcoming. "Sue" is a fully mounted cast of the most complete Tyrannosaurus Rex ever unearthed. This exhibit will include video footage, interactives, touchable replicas and colorful graphics. The casting of "Sue" is being done at The Field Museum in Chicago. The Field Museum acquired "Sue" in October, 1997. The full-size cast of Sue’s skeleton is mounted in a life-like pose on a free standing base. Currently planned for installation on the basement level of the Blue Wing.

product.title: WCRB Kids Classical Promotion
product.description: T. rex promotional event with WCRB

product.title: WODS/ T. rex "Fossil Frenzy"
product.description: WODS on-site Wednesday, June 28 from 1-3pm in main lobby.

product.title: Ronald McDonald Library Event
product.description: Ronald McDonald will be on-site to promote the Museum's summer reading program and A T. rex named Sue. This event is NOT open to the public and is from 10:30 - 12:00pm

product.title: Mix 98.5 "BLAST!" Promotion
product.description:
On Friday, August 25 listeners of Mix 98.5 fm will be encouraged to visit the Museum of Science. Patrons who show their BLAST! ticket stub receive two dollars off the price of admission.
BLAST! is an "explosive musical" from London's West End. It is performing at the Wang Theater from August 22 - August 27.
Mix 98.5 fm will be on site at the main lobby of the Museum of Science from 4-6pm on Friday August 25.

product.title: Take 5 for Science Film Shoot
product.description: On Friday, September 8 at 7:00am WCVB-TV Channel 5 will be on-site at the Museum to film our lastest installment in the "Take 5 for Science" series that appears on Channel 5. This shoot will take place in the Natural Mysteries exhibit. The shoot should last into the early afternoon. The exhibit should remain open throughout the shoot, however there is the possibilty that it may have to be stanchioned off for a short period of time.

product.title: American Express Customer Appreciation Night
product.description: American Express Financial Advisors will be on-site to host a customer appreciation night. Guests register attend via telephone to American Express' financial advice radio show, which airs Sunday Mornings on Oldies 103.3 fm. Guests enjoy appetizers in the Atrium and then view a financial advice presentation as well as the featured Omni film. The event beigns at 6:00 and concludes at 9:00 pm

Guests enjoy appetizers in the Atrium and then view a financial advice presentation as well as the featured Omni film. The event beigns at 6:00 and concludes at 9:00 pm

product.description: Press Opening: Powers of Nature. October 6, 2000 at 10:00 am

product.title: Powers of Nature
product.description: This is a 6,000 sq. ft. exhibit that examines extraordinary natural phenomena: earthquakes, storms and volcanoes. Through a combination of interactive devices, experiments, graphic illustrations, computer activities and personal stories, "Powers of Nature" will provide visitors with a basic understanding of the strength and science of these powerful phenomena, what causes them to occur, how we monitor and predict them, and how they affect our lives.

product.title: WODS/ Land O' Lakes "Touch of Class" Promotion
Oldies 103.3 fm "Adventures in Wild California" promotion
product.description: Oldies 103.3 fm will be on site to host a special screening of "Adventures in Wild California" All guests will have won tickets on Oldies 103.3. They will set up a promo table in the Atrium and introduce the film in the Omni Theater. They will also raffle off a trip to California. Winner mst in present to win!

product.title: Press Opening: If These Walls Could Talk
product.description: 10am

product.title: If These Walls Could Talk: An Exhibit About Buildings
product.description: Visitors walk inside models of buildings, such as a "Mongolian Ger." The walls are opened up to show some unique materials so they can see what it’s made out of. There is the "Skyscraper Area", where visitors are immersed in an environment of bolted steel, glass and concrete. Visitors are given the illusion (with the help of a 3D viewer) of working forty stories above the ground and experience the sensation of looking down the side of a building. Every building has a story to tell, has clues about their age, function and the people who live in them.

product.title: CS&T Center (opening)
product.description: A permanent facility on the 1st floor of the Blue Wing that will be the locus of constantly changing exhibits and programs on what's new in science and technology.

product.title: "Shackleton's Way" Book Signing with Margot Merrell

product.title: Autonomous Vehicles & Robotic Tuna
product.description: A collection of various robotic vehicles and devices created by Draper Labs. Located in the Current Science & Technology Center

product.description: Major temporary exhibit on Egyptian quest for immortality, including artifacts and recreation of the burial tomb of Pharaoh Thutmosis III

Magic: The Science of Illusion

product.title: Einstein
product.description: View the world through Einstein's eyes. Exhibit from AMNH

product.description: A seasonal historic display connected to the Duck Tour program

product.title: The Lord of the Rings Motion Picture Trilogy - The Exhibition
product.description: Artifacts and activities related to the film trilogy

product.title: Strange Matter
product.description: Ontario Science Center Exhibit. 6,000 sq. ft, Stearns Gallery. Website: www.strangematterexhibit.com

product.title: Playing with Time
product.description: Travelling exhibit about time and technology to "manipulate" it. Nichols. Website: Playingwithtime.org

product.title: Playing by the Rules: Fish, Fads, and Fireflies
product.description: A collection of interactive displays on rule based behavior and emergent behavior as a related thematic exhibit to the Making Models activity center. Featuring the Museum's redesigned Virtual FishTank.

product.title: Butterfly Garden
product.description: A walk-through live butterfly conservatory featuring native and tropical species along with associated displays on how butterflies and plants have adapted to each other over millions of years.

product.title: Beyond the X-ray
product.description: Removed Aug 18-22 to travel to other venues

product.title: Brain: The World Inside Your Head
product.description: Clear Channel Exhibit. 5,000 sq.ft interactive, high tech exhibit. Nichols. Images, info & teacher's guide on website: www.clearchannelexhibitions.com

product.title: Wind Energy - Forum Tech Initiative
product.description: Featuring a computer based visitor response system. Location: Blue Wing, Basement.

product.title: Wind Power - Showcase Tech Initiative
product.description: Located in the lower well, Basement Blue Wing.

product.title: Human Evolution
product.description: A new look at Human Evolution located in the Human Body Connection discovery space

product.title: WeatherWise
product.description: A new exhibit in the Theater of Electricity focusing on "nowcasting" and helping visitors to understand how they can predict the weather using information available to them.

product.title: Star Wars: Where Science Meets Imagination
product.description: Description details at www.starwars.mos.org Nichols

product.title: Modern Marvels
product.description: Highlights 25 modern-day inventors that are chosen as semi-finalists in a Challenge put forth by the National Inventors Hall of Fame and The History Channel. Located at rear of main lobby.

product.title: Body Worlds
product.description:
Exhibit info on web page:
www.bodyworlds.com

product.title: Robots & Us
product.description: Minnesota's SMEC exhibit. Tent. scheduled for Stearns. Website: www.robotsandus.org

product.title: Animation
product.description: Produced by OMSI. Stearns Gallery. Website: www.omsi.edu/visit.featured/animation

product.title: Colossal
product.description: Exhibit of Bradford Washburns Photographs to be displayed outside of Nichols gallery http://www.panopt.com/photogra/washburn/gallerybw.html

product.title: Grand Canyon Model
product.description: The Museum's large Contour Model of the Grand Canyon is being shown for the first time in many years to accompany the Grand Canyon Omni Film. Brad Washburn's work in mapping the Grand Canyon and his legacy at the Museum will be briefly touched upon. The model is located in the Omni Atrium and will remain through two runs of the GC Omni film.

product.title: Discovering Chimpanzees: The Remarkable World of Jane Goodall
product.description:
Jane Goodall’s message, conveyed in the traveling exhibit is one of hope…individuals working together can make a difference in the struggle to protect these creatures and to preserve the planet’s biodiversity and our natural heritage. This exhibit involves visitors with an array of interactive exhibits which explore the amazing world of chimpanzees, their primate relatives, and the work of Jane Goodall.
Five theme areas: Entrance – Enter the exhibit through a large façade of the forest of Gombe National Park. The Chimp Forest – Simulated forest environment where visitors are invited to “Be a Chimp”. The Work of Jane Goodall – Field notes, photographs, video clips, and artifacts bringing to life Dr. Goodall’s 40 years of research. Primates – Exhibits on the primate order. Reason for Hope – this area of the exhibit celebrates individuals who have taken action to deal with environmental and societal issues.
Info & images on website: discoveringchimpanzees.com

product.title: Innovative Engineers /Design Challenge Lab
product.description: This exhibit will embody the goals of the National Center for Technological Literacy. It will invite visitors of all ages to explore the work of engineers and reflect upon the breakthroughs that entieers have contributed to our world. It will encourage visitors to learn about the engineering process and discover the variety of engieering careers available.

product.title: CSI: The Experience
product.description: This totally immersive traveling exhibit brings to life modern scientific principles and real investigative techniques used by crime scene investigators and forensic scientists. Guided by investigators from the CBS series “CSI” along with their real-life forensic science counterparts, guests go from a Firearms Lab where they match shell casings, to a realistic Autopsy Room where a forensic pathologist is explaining “liver mortis,” to a Toxicology Lab where a victim’s blood is tested for venomous toxins, as well as many other hands-on experiences set in exciting visual environments that fans of “CSI” will recognize. Guests will identify evidence at the crime scene for detailed analysis; analyze evidence in a crime lab using the latest scientific and technological advances; formulate a hypothesis about the crime based on analysis; and validate and communicate their findings based on scientific evidence.

product.title: Take a Closer Look
product.description: Seeing the Unseen, the first Activity Center of the Science is an Activity plan has been refurbished and has a brand new look to it. New components, new content, and some old favorites can be seen in its new location on Lower Level Blue Wing.

product.title: Lizards & Snakes: Alive
product.description:
This exhibit features 20 cases with over 60 live lizards and snakes from five continents, “Lizards & Snakes: Alive!” introduces audiences to these adaptable, colorful, sometimes dangerous organisms. Using live animals, real and cast fossils, extensive multimedia, hands-on interactives, and an activity area specifically for young visitors, “Lizards & Snakes: Alive” is a fascinating look into the world of squamates that will enthrall, educate, and engage visitors of all ages.
Theme Areas: A World of Sights – Explores the evolution of squamate vision. Smelling in Tongues – Examines the evolution of squamates who use their tongues to sense the world around them. Life without Limbs – Explores the evolution of snakes & snake traits, including heat sensing, deadly venom, constriction, and expandable jaws. Squamate Studio - A hands-on area for younger visitors & their parents that explores many of the evolutionary and behavioral squamate traits explained throughout the exhibit.
Exhibit Website: http://www.amnh.org/exhibitions/lizards/

product.title: Double Exposure: Photographing Global Climate Change
product.description: 14 pairs of images, each pair including a photo by Brad Washburn taken approximately 70 years ago and one taken today by David Arnold of the same glacier formation, showing the changes over time. Also included will be two large (approximately 15 foot long) panoramic views.

product.title: Baseball As America
product.description:
This exhibition takes the visitor on an in-depth look into the history of the sport of baseball and its connection to American culture. The exhibit features over 500 artifacts from the National Baseball Hall of Fame & Museum.
Theme Areas: Our National Spirit – Links between the pastime and our national identity. Ideals & Injustices – Examines the growth of American social equality and multiculturalism through baseball. Rooting for the Team – Examines the role of the fans Enterprise & Opportunity – The business of baseball, products, franchises, etc. Sharing a Common Culture – Baseball’s influence on popular culture. Invention and Ingenuity – The invention and science of baseball. Weaving Myths – Folk heroes and cultural icons of baseball.
Exhibit Website: http://www.baseballasamerica.org/exhibition_8.html

product.title: Goose Bumps! The Science of Fear
product.description: Produced by the California Science Center. Fear is a normal part of everyone’s life, but remains a misunderstood emotion. Goose Bumps! will allow visitors to experience fear in a safe and enjoyable environment, measure their physical responses, understand the science behind the emotion, and reflect upon its personal meaning.

product.title: Adrenaline Rush (3rd cycle)
product.description: Adrenaline Rush: The Science of Risk takes audiences on a breathtaking journey from extraordinary heights, featuring spectacular footage of extreme skydiving and focusing as well on both the biology of risk-taking and the physics that make human flight possible. The audience will meet scientists and skydivers Adrian Nicholas and Katrina Ollikainen, developers of the world's most advanced skydiving wing suit, then witness their dramatic experiment in which the 15th century specifications and drawings of Leonardo DaVinci's parachute design are put to the ultimate test of flight.

product.title: Sky Heroes: Myths in the Stars
product.description: Feature Planetarium show to coincide with exhibit "Mythic Creatures." Show will focus on constellation mythology from around the world. Approximately 40 minutes long. Appropriate for adults, families, schools.

product.title: Mythic Creatures: Dragons, Unicorns & Mermaids
product.description: The world is full of stories about brave heroes, magical events and fantastic beings. For thousands of years, humans everywhere— sometimes inspired by living animals or even fossils—have brought mythic creatures to life in stories, songs and works of art. Today these creatures, from the powerful dragon to the soaring phoenix, continue to thrill, terrify, entertain and inspire us. We seem to catch glimpses of these creatures all around us: hiding beneath the ocean waves, running silently through the forest and soaring among the clouds. Some symbolize danger. Others, we think, can bring us luck or joy. Together mythic creatures give shape to humankind's greatest hopes, fears and most passionate dreams. The exhibit is divided into 4 theme areas: Water - Creatures of the Deep This section contains the topics: sea monsters in cultures around the world, information on real animals like the giant squid which many sea monsters may be based on, the depiction of mythic killer whales in Nazca culture (Peru 1 -700 AD), mermaid myths, discussion on how legends of mythic creatures have changed through cultural interaction & through the course of time, & the Chinese water dragon. Land – Creatures of the Earth This section contains the topics: How fossils have inspired mythical creatures, the griffin & dinosaur fossils, giants & Cyclopes in Greek mythology & fossils that may have spurred these legends, Unicorns & narwhal tusks, bringing mythic creatures to life through cultural reenactments, modern mythic creatures like the chupacabra & Bigfoot, & depictions of land dragons in different cultures. Air – Creatures of the Sky This section contains the topics: Greek air creatures like the sphinx & Pegasus, the mythic Roc & other large birds, the largest birds that have lived on earth, an exploration of the pairing of mythic creatures like Naga & Garuda in Hindu mythology, mythic birds with great powers like the phoenix, an exploration of the purpose of myths, & air dragons like the Aztec god, Quetzalcoatl. Dragons – Creatures of Power This section contains the topics: European dragons, Asian dragons, the imperial dragon of China, cultural borrowing of dragon myths, & the natural history of dragons (a changing interpretation through time of natural items & people linked to dragons).

product.title: Terrafugia Transition
product.description: Private pilots today are often grounded by bad weather, high operating costs, and a general lack of ground transportation at most general aviation airports. These factors combine to make flying impractical for the majority of the private general aviation community. Terrafugia Inc. is developing the Transition® Personal Air Vehicle, a novel aircraft that is capable of folding its wings, driving on the highway, and parking in a standard garage. The Transition® allows pilots to drive when the weather is bad, giving them tremendous transportation flexibility. It saves money on both gasoline and hangar rental, and it provides pilots with a ride wherever they might land, saving time and hassle, while reducing their impact on the environment. The Terrafugia Transition® will transform personal aviation for tens of thousands of pilots around the world. The exhibit will consist of a prototype of the Terrafugia Transition Light-Sport Aircraft (LSA) with brief explanatory signage.

product.title: Nothing But Nets
product.description:
Exhibit produced by United Nations Foundation’s, Nothing But Nets Campaign. Nothing But Nets is a grassroots campaign to save lives by preventing malaria, a leading killer of children in Africa. The organization’s primary role is in encouraging donations to purchase & distribute insecticide-treated bed nets to at-risk countries.
The small display will include several conical net displays 7’(h) x4’(w)x 3’(d) surrounding a larger central bed with full-size canopy net along with information tables & carts. Staff from Nothing But Nets will be on-site with the display to talk to visitors about malaria & inform them on ways they can get involved in combating this disease. Visitors will also have the opportunity to fill out hope cards to send a message of hope to a refugee in Africa receiving a donated net.

product.title: Frogs: A Chorus of Colors
product.description:
Frogs – A Chorus of Colors is a modular traveling exhibition that introduces visitors to the amazing and sonorous world of anurans – the frogs. Although most people have no aversion to frogs, their beauty and elegance are often overlooked. These amphibians are among the most visually stunning, vocally pleasing and adaptively remarkable life forms on earth. If you’ve never thought of frogs as beautiful, this exhibition will change your mind!
Frogs – A Chorus of Colors is designed to transform an exhibit gallery and offer visitors the feel of a frog’s world. Stunning backlighted graphic panels with colorful images by Joe McDonald, Dave Northcott, John Netherton, Bill Love and other renowned wildlife photographers cover the walls of the exhibition island. Frog habitats, complete with rock ledges, live plants and waterfalls, protrude through the island walls. Living frogs from around the world offer a glimpse of the vast pallet of frog diversity. Sturdy interactive components invite visitors to activate recorded frog calls, touch models, view videos of frogs in action, spin a zoetrope, and test frog knowledge on subjects from basic to bizarre. Throughout the exhibition visitors are immersed in the sights and sounds of frogs.
The exhibition includes 15 frog habitats complete with naturalistic decor, filtration and life support systems; 12 interactive components; and over 35 backlighted informative panels.

product.title: Manufactured Landscapes: Photographic Works By Edward Burtynsky
product.description:
The exhibit will be composed of 12 large prints (approximately 50”x60”) by the Canadian photographer Edward Burtynsky. Edward Burtynsky's imagery explores the intricate connection between industry and nature; combining the raw elements of mining, quarrying, manufacturing, shipping, oil production and recycling into eloquent, highly expressive visions that find beauty and humanity in the most unlikely of places.
Artist’s Statement: Nature transformed through industry is a predominant theme in my work. I set course to intersect with a contemporary view of the great ages of man; from stone, to minerals, oil, transportation, silicon, and so on. To make these ideas visible I search for subjects that are rich in detail and scale yet open in their meaning. Recycling yards, mine tailings, quarries and refineries are all places that are outside of our normal experience, yet we partake of their output on a daily basis.
These images are meant as metaphors to the dilemma of our modern existence; they search for a dialogue between attraction and repulsion, seduction and fear. We are drawn by desire - a chance at good living, yet we are consciously or unconsciously aware that the world is suffering for our success. Our dependence on nature to provide the materials for our consumption and our concern for the health of our planet sets us into an uneasy contradiction. For me, these images function as reflecting pools of our times.
Show originally closing 09-07-2009 extended to 09-13-2009.

product.title: National Geographic Crittercam: The World through Animal Eyes
product.description: Investigate the natural world from a new perspective! This exhibition explores ongoing research with National Geographic Crittercam, a scientific video and data gathering tool safely worn by wild animals. With multimedia activities, evocative environments, and mesmerizing firsthand footage, Crittercam will allow visitors to experience the world from an animal's point of view. Based on more than 20 years of invention and research collaborations spanning the globe, Crittercam offers new insights into animal behavior and provides clues about how to protect our planet's creatures and the world we share.

product.title: Journey to the Edge of Space and Time
product.description: Journey to the farthest reaches of space and time and the cutting edge of scientific knowledge. Approximately 40 minutes long. Appropriate for families, adults and school groups.

product.title: Black Holes: Space Warps and Time Twists
product.description:
This exhibit uses the enormous popularity of black holes to engage visitors in active learning about the nature of scientific discovery; the size, scale, and structure of the universe; and the nature of gravity and other core concepts in physical science.
Black holes are an ideal vehicle for engaging the public in exploring the nature of science—including the idea that extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence, and the wonderful idea that nature can be much stranger than our intuitions would guess. Advances in exhibitry and scientific visualizations have now made it possible for visitors to explore even the strangest ideas underlying black holes and the extremes of gravity, in a variety of sensory modalities. At the same time, much of the evidence for black holes is both dramatic and accessible to general audiences—making it possible for the public to weigh for themselves whether black holes have moved from the realm of science fiction to the status of reality.
In this exhibit you’ll combine the roles of scientist, explorer, and reporter as you take on a challenging mission—to find out the inside story of black holes. Do they really exist? Are they friend or foe (or both)? What’s the fuss and why are they considered so exciting? What’s so mysterious about them? You’ll have the opportunity to capture your experiences and observations for later reference, because the exhibit will automatically create a personalized website for you.
You'll find three areas in this exhibit: An introductory area will help orient you to the new world of black holes. An exploration area offers you hands-on opportunities to investigate the latest evidence, images, and theories about these mysterious beasts, with the video-based assistance of both scientist and teen guides. And the black hole mission area will provide the signature experience of this exhibit, a virtual journey to the black hole at the center of our galaxy.

product.title: Planet You 3D
product.description: Discover the ecosystem on your skin and some of what happens there as part of daily life. Join us for a light-hearted but some might say creepy look at that unique world we call Planet You.

product.title: The Moon: 40 Years from Apollo
product.description: Feature show about the past, present and future of the Moon, showing one day only in celebration of the 40th anniversary of the first human landing on another world--Apollo 11. Approximately 40 minutes long. Appropriate for families, adults and school groups.

product.title: From Earth to the Universe
product.description: The exhibit consists of 15 o 18 stands of astronomical images. Each sign is double-sided so there will be a total of 30 to 36 distinct images on display. Several of the images are currently being displayed in the Black Holes exhibit & will be combined with several new images in a small display on the Museum’s front plaza. The Museum has decided to host the exhibit in celebration of the 10th anniversary of the important Cambridge-based Chandra X-ray telescope. There will be several images in this display taken by the Chandra telescope.

product.title: What Happened to Pluto?
product.description: Explore our beautiful Solar System and its thousands of varied worlds--planets, moons, comets, asteroids, and newly-found objects beyond Pluto--and learn why scientists now call Pluto a dwarf planet. Approximately 40 minutes long. Appropriate for families, adults and school groups.

product.title: Wild Music: Sounds & Songs of Life
product.description:
Exhibit Overview: Wild Music explores evidence for the biological origins of music through highly interactive exhibits and exceptional sound experiences, and -- in the process -- expands our understandings of what makes music. With its multicultural content, careful attention to accessibility, and rich menu of public programs and performances, Wild Music offers broad appeal for diverse, intergenerational audiences.
5 Theme Areas: The Forest’s Edge – In this area visitors can hunt for sounds of forest creatures and explore exhibits about birdsong and soundscapes.
Bioacoustics Laboratory – The Bioacoustics Laboratory invites visitors to explore sound and song more closely through a series of experiences – a touchable spectrum analyzer, working models of a human larynx and bird syrinx, and experiments with resonance.
The Town – An immersive environment of a town square where human sounds predominate.
The Power of Music – A small theater which runs a film on the power of sound and song, across species, to help us bond, to work together, and to grieve.
The Ocean Deeps – This area of the exhibit draws visitors to investigate the songs of whales – resembling human song, they learn their phrasing, rhythm, and variations on basic themes.

product.title: Running the Numbers: Portraits of Mass Consumption
product.description:
Running the Numbers looks at contemporary American culture through the austere lens of statistics. Each image portrays a specific quantity of something: fifteen million sheets of office paper (five minutes of paper use); 106,000 aluminum cans (thirty seconds of can consumption) and so on. Statistics can feel abstract and anesthetizing, making it difficult to connect with and make meaning of large numbers. This project visually examines these vast and bizarre measures of our society, in large intricately detailed prints assembled from thousands of smaller photographs. The goal is that images representing these quantities might have a different effect than the raw numbers alone.
The version of this exhibit to be displayed at the Museum of Science will contain 7 distinct prints. Details below:
Gyre (96x44” x 3 panels) Depicts 2.4 million pieces of plastic, equal to the estimated number of pounds of plastic pollution that enter the world's oceans every hour. All of the plastic in this image was collected from the Pacific Ocean.
Plastic Cups (60x90”) Depicts one million plastic cups, the number used on airline flights in the US every six hours.
Cans Seurat (60x92”) Depicts 106,000 aluminum cans, the number used in the US every thirty seconds.
Cell Phones (60x100”) Depicts 426,000 cell phones, equal to the number of cell phones retired in the US every day.
Jet Trails (60x96”) Depicts 11,000 jet trails, equal to the number of commercial flights in the US every eight hours.
Paper Bags (60x80”) Depicts 1.14 million brown paper supermarket bags, the number used in the US every hour.
Plastic Bottles (60x120”) Depicts two million plastic beverage bottles, the number used in the US every five minutes.

product.title: Winterlight: Stars and Symbols of the Solstice
product.description: Holiday show about the winter solstice and celebrations from around the world. Appropriate for families, schools, and adults. Approximately 40 minutes long.

product.title: Catching the Wind
product.description: Wind Power exhibit located on Basement Level Blue Wing. Explains Museum's roof top Wind Lab which includes 5 styles of working turbines.

product.title: Identity: An Exhibition of You
product.description:
“Identity: an Exhibition of You” challenges our notions of personal identity. The exhibit uses the familiar (our body, our thoughts, our relationships) to make connections with the scientific (our genes, our brains, our roles in society).
Your own identity is front and center while you learn about genetics and biological identity; cognitive science/psychology and personality; and social science and racial/ethnic identity. Look at your own fingerprints, see your personality as a musical spectrum, investigate where your brain stores your identity, map your social connections, and throughout the exhibition, see yourself from new perspectives: your future self, your symmetrical self, and yourself as a new gender or ethnicity.

product.title: Nothing But Nets
product.description:
One day display by United Nations Foundation to promote malaria prevention awareness project through the distribution of bed nets (that protect against mosquitos) to areas in Africa.
Exhibit produced by United Nations Foundation. Nothing But Nets is a grassroots campaign to save lives by preventing malaria, a leading killer of children in Africa. The organization’s primary role is in encouraging donations to purchase & distribute insecticide-treated bed nets to at-risk countries.
The small display will include a net display along with information tables & carts. Staff from Nothing But Nets will be on-site with the display to talk to visitors about malaria & inform them on ways they can get involved in combating this disease. Visitors will also have the opportunity to fill out hope cards to send a message of hope to a refugee in Africa receiving a donated net.

product.title: Israeli Innovation Technology Week
product.description: Displays will hilight various technology innovations developed in Israel. The State of Israel has evolved into a world leader in the clean technology and life science fields. Because of its proximity to a desert area and instable rainfall, Israel has developed unique expertise in water and environmental technology long before “cleantech” was invented. Israel’s expertise in renewable energy originated in the research and development of solar-thermal and geo-thermal technologies, a field that Israel had gained global leadership. There are over 100 renewable energy companies, over 270 water companies, and numerous other companies focused on environmental technologies.

product.title: Inside the Mind of M.C. Escher
product.description: The Museum’s new temporary exhibit explores the work of Maurits Cornelis Escher, one of the world’s most famous graphic artists. The exhibit features 16 high-quality reproductions of Escher masterworks and activities that invite visitors to explore some of the ideas that so fascinated the artist. Through his woodcuts and lithographs Escher wandered through the concepts of symmetry, plane geometry, spherical and hyperbolic geometry, and the representation of infinity within a finite space. We invite you to contemplate impossible structures, explore how tessellations are created, and bend your mind as you sketch your own spherical reflection.

product.title: Whales/Tohora
product.description: Visitors will be amazed by the diversity of whales. They will discover the whale-riding traditions of the South Pacific, learn about the origins of whales, and be awed by the colossal whale skeletons. They can touch a replica of a sperm whale’s tooth, clamber through a blue whales heart, and dive to great depths with a mighty sperm whale in the hunt for a giant squid. The exhibit contains 4 sub-sections: Introduction: Visitors to the exhibit are welcomed into the underwater world of whales Whale People: In this section, visitors meet some of the people whose lives have been inextricably linked with whales – from legendary South Pacific whale riders, to whale scientists and former whaling families. It explores the changing attitudes to whales & whaling. Whale Lab: In the Whale Lab visitors can explore the biology of whales and find out about their extraordinary lifestyles – from some of the smallest dolphins to the mightiest creature on Earth Strandings: This section explores the mystery of whale strandings, both mass and single strandings, and explores how people respond to whale strandings. For some, stranded whales are gifts from the sea. For others, they are rare opportunities to study these creatures. And many people want to help save them.

product.title: Aesthetics and Astronomy: Studying the Public’s Perception and Understanding of non-traditional Imagery across Multiple Platforms
product.description:
Images of the cosmos provide snapshots of various phases of life and death, different physical phenomena, found in locations across the known Universe. Today, some 400 years after Galileo created his, modern telescopes have enabled us to “see” what the human eye cannot. This new generation of ground- and space-based telescopes has created an explosion of images for the public to explore.
The exhibit includes 6 astronomical Images & 1 banner as well as a research component where, at select times, visitors will be surveyed onsite. This survey will study visitors’ perceptions of multi-wavelength astronomical imagery and the effects of the scientific and artistic choices in processing astronomical data. The images come from a variety of space and ground-based observatories, including the Chandra X-ray Observatory, Hubble Space Telescope, Spitzer Space Telescope, the Very Large Array, the Hinode satellite, and many others. Evaluation of such valuable data will benefit astronomy across the electromagnetic spectrum of astronomical images, and may help visualization of data in other scientific disciplines.

product.title: George Washington Carver
product.description:
The exhibit is organized into 5 sections: Carver’s Mighty Mission: George Washington Carver envisioned a world of peace and prosperity that could be fulfilled through exploring and investigating nature. A brief introductory text panel and video explain that Dr. Carver was a complex and fascinating individual whose contributions extend far beyond his notable work with peanuts, and whose teachings have special relevance to problems faced by the world today. Visitors can discover George Washington Carver’s life an achievements, beginning with the amazing story of his earliest days.
From Slave to Scholar: Born a slave, orphaned as an infant and plagued by ill health, Dr. carver overcame enormous obstacles. This section recounts the story of Dr. Carver’s childhood, including his dramatic rescue from slave raiders, early signs of genius, and 20-year quest for education.
People’s Scientist: Dr. Carver’s life’s work was dedicated to “helping the man lowest down.” It was because of his dedication to service that he chose to leave the abundant resources of Iowa State College for Tuskegee Institute, where he focused his research on topics that would improve the lives of farmers. Upon arriving in Alabama and seeing the “acres of scraggly cotton,” Dr. Carver immediately knew what was wrong with Southern soil – and how to fix it. The focus point of this section and symbol of his lifelong commitment to humanitarian goals is a life-size reproduction of the original Jesup wagon, a school on wheels designed by Dr. Carver.
Plant Power: This section recreated Dr. Carver’s lab to help tell the story of his experiments with peanuts, sweet potatoes, and other plants.
Carver’s Legacy: The closing section of the exhibition explores Dr. Carver’s scientific and lifelong humanitarian legacy. This section will feature contemporary research in medicinal plants, bio-products, and fuels, including studies now underway at the Carver Agricultural Research Station at Tuskegee University. This section also touches on Dr. Carver’s exemplary lifestyle – his discipline, hobbies, and eccentricities that endeared him to the general public. Dr. Carver saw all of his disparate activities and endeavors as part of a singular quest for truth and understanding of the world. His unique worldview and the example of his life are perhaps his most powerful legacy.

product.title: LaserLab
product.description:
Visitors of all ages can explore the science behind lasers – 50 years after their invention – in the LaserLab.
How are laser beams created? Where can we find lasers in everyday life? How can a laser make light appear around corner? These are just a few of the questions that the LaserLab playfully answers for visitors through 7 interactive exhibit components.
A laser foosball table is a highlight of the LaserLab. Visitors can put their newly-acquired understanding of lasers to use. The laser foosball game works just like normal foosball. But the ball is a laser beam that has to be directed into the goal with the help of adjustable mirrors.

product.title: Reptiles: The Beautiful and the Deadly
product.description:
Reptiles have enduring public appeal, and this interactive zoological exhibition brings visitors eyeball to eyeball with living species from around the world. Deadly snakes, colorful lizards, bizarre turtles, and rugged crocodilians are exhibited in naturalistic habitats.
Engaging interactives, and bold interpretive graphics explore the major groups of modern "cold-blooded" reptiles with cutting-edge science and conservation themes. Visitors can "milk" a viper, learn to speak croc in under five minutes, and test their knowlege with "Turtle Trivia" or "Lizard Wizard". The experience is meant to explode common myths and foster a basic understanding of how reptiles fit into the animal kingdom and their native environments.

product.title: K'NEX: Building Thrill Rides
product.description:
K'NEX: Building Thrill Rides is all about exploring and understanding the Science and Engineering that goes into creating the amazing experiences that are offered at theme parks! The following full size K’NEX models will be included in the exhibit: 6’ Ferris Wheels (3) 6’ Boom Ride 10’ Roller Coaster 6’ Double Star Ferris Wheel Serpent Spiral Roller Coaster Vertical Vengeance Roller Coaster Small Ferris Wheel Roller Coaster Ramp Swing Rides (2) Carousel Octopus Ride Starburst Spinner Small Double Star Ferris Wheel
With the addition of Kid K'NEX and K'NEX Building stations, children, parents, teachers, and others can build what ever they can imagine with an unlimited supply of K'NEX pieces. Visitors will have an option to purchase what they have built at the Weigh and Pay sales counters in the exhibit based on the weight of the object.

product.title: RACE: Are We So Different?
product.description:
People are different. Throughout history, these differences have been a source of community strength and personal identity. They have also been the basis for discrimination and oppression.
The idea of "race" has been used historically to describe these differences and justify mistreatment of people and even genocide. Today, contemporary scientific understanding of human variation is beginning to challenge "racial" differences, and even question the very concept of race.
RACE: Are We So Different?, developed by the American Anthropological Association in collaboration with the Science Museum of Minnesota, is the first national exhibition to tell the stories of race from the biological, cultural, and historical points of view. Combining these perspectives offers an unprecedented look at race and racism in the United States.

product.title: Diabetes: A Deeper Look
product.description: Diabetes: A Deeper Look is a series of 22 interactive displays built in and around a giant walk-through blood vessel. The hands-on exhibit is designed to help reach large audiences, including people living with diabetes, their friends and families, caregivers, treating healthcare providers, students and community members not yet diagnosed. Visitors to the exhibit enter through a giant cell structure that simulates how insulin helps get glucose into cells. Inside and around the vessel, hands-on interactive exhibits and displays will explain the role of insulin; how people can be affected by diabetes; the importance of diet and exercise as the first line of defense to preventing and managing type 2 diabetes; the types of medications used to help control blood sugar levels, including insulin; and the research and discovery of medications used to help treat diabetes.

product.title: New England in a Different Light: Ifrared New England Landscapes
product.description: New England in a Different Light: Infrared New England Landscapes contains15 photographs of New England landscapes produced through use of a specialized infrared filter. The human eye sees a narrow range of electromagnetic radiation, from ultraviolet to the colors of the rainbow. Most digital camera sensors are sensitive to near-infrared light which we cannot see with our eyes. Using a specialized infrared filter, Artist Guy Biechele brings a new perspective to common New England scenes.

product.title: Mindscapes: The Aerial Photography of Adriel Heisey
product.description:
With the control stick strapped to his knee and his hands free to work, Adriel Heisey navigates his hand-built Ultra-light aircraft slowly over the land, his lens open to what lies below. The results are mysterious and compelling images that move between pure documentation and powerful abstraction. Their visual power invokes memories, associations, and emotions that are rooted the in vast landscape of the American Southwest.
Mindscapes: The Aerial Photography of Adriel Heisey is a beautifully framed set of 27 dramatic color photographs, including personal observations by the artist about each print.
"My work lives in a place that quietly breathes with infinite form and color, a place that both invites and resists the grasp of the human imagination. A place unparalleled, a place from the sky." -A.H.
Heisey's photographs are in private and corporate collections worldwide. His images have been published in National Geographic, Smithsonian, Geo, and Natural History. He is author of the book Under the Sun: A Sonoran Desert Odyssey.

product.title: Voices Without Faces, Voices Without Races: an audio journey
product.description:
To organize and simplify the world around us, we use broad strokes to label people and places, often relying on stereotypes. These simplifications stand in marked contrast to the rich and complex ways in which we identify ourselves, our neighborhoods, and our hometowns. Boston’s long history of diversity and change is unknown to many and often overshadowed by well-known periods of racial tension and conflict. Today, the Greater Boston area is home to a wealth of ethnicities and cultures, a vivid tapestry exemplified in the neighborhoods along Route 28, which stretches from country to the north, through suburbs and manufacturing towns, past the Museum and through the heart of Boston, and down to Cape Cod.
Sound artist Halsey Burgund and the Museum of Science collected the voices of over 250 people who live along the Route 28 corridor. The result is Voices Without Faces, Voices Without Races, a compelling collage of personal stories that reveal how we are all different and how we are the same.

product.title: Museum Then and Now
product.description: A retrospect display about the Museum of Science. Artifacts from the collection closet and historic Museum photos are on display on the upper level of the Theater of Electricity Building.

product.title: Energized!
product.description: Exhibit on renewable and green electric energy sources located in Basement Blue Wing

product.title: Dinosaurs: Ancient Fossils, New Discoveries
product.description:
Imagine the thrill of Discovering something brand- new about a creature that lived millions of years ago. Ever since the first dinosaur fossil was identified almost 200 years ago, people have wondered how these fascinating animals lived, moved and behaved. At first, dinosaur hunters used only such tools as a keen eye, shovels and compasses. Today, scientists also rely on everything from satellite technology to scanning electron microscopes.
Prepare to take a journey of discovery into the exciting world of modern paleontology. New dinosaur fossils are being discovered faster than ever before. Advanced technology allows scientists to look at these fossils in fresh ways. And researchers are gaining surprising insights into these amazing animals. New discoveries, new technology and new ideas are helping today's scientists piece together what these living, breathing dinosaurs were really like. The exhibit is separated into 5 theme sections; Introduction, How Dinosaurs Moved, How Dinosaurs Behaved, The Liaoning Forest, and Extinction.

product.title: In The Dark
product.description: The dark – a place of mystery. Sometimes scary, but always intriguing, darkeness beckons exploration. Darkness is also a natural evolutionary selective pressure that has caused plants and animals to adapt to dark ecosystems like caves, the deep sea, the forest at night, and underneath the ground. Since prehistoric times humans have sought to understand the function of darkness, and have invented ways to change it. Guests explore and so9lve some of these mysteries of the dark using electronic, mechanical and computer interactives, walkthrough or around dioramas, fiberglass models, and graphic panels. Theme Areas: The Darkness of Night (Nocturnal Environments) – Through dioramas & interactives, visitors explore nocturnal animals in three different habitats, the great Smoky Mountains, the Sonoran Desert, and a Louisiana cypress swamp. Darkness within the Soil (Underground Environments) – Focusing attention closer to home, the exhibit takes a look at the soil beneath human feet. A cross-section of a backyard reveals it to be teaming with life such as moles, termites, cicadas, worms, and slugs living within the seemingly solid substrate. Darkness Deep within Caves (Caverns) – caves offer a refuge that is completely without light. Guests receive a dramatic introduction to one type of cave as they walk through a recreation of a Kentucky cave formed by the slow action of water dissolving the limestone over millennia. This cavern is inhabited both by animals looking for temporary darkness during the day, such as bats, and by animals whose ancestors wandered deeper into the cave and never re-emerged, such as blind cave fish, cave flatworms and cave crayfish. Darkness of the Deep Sea (Deep Sea Environments) – This area of the exhibit plummets into the depths of the sea, offering a glimpse of an environment that I not only eternally dark, but that does not even depend on the world of light for its source of energy. This area of the exhibit explores animals that thrive near sulfur vents, by feeding on bacteria, and those that survive by feeding off of the photosynthetic plankton that drift down from the area of light. Darkness and Humans (Humans in the Dark) – In an urban residential setting, the exhibit examines the interaction of humans with darkness. Guests can explore myths and legends of different human cultures to interpret night and darkness as well as technological adaptations to the dark, including technologies developed to assist the blind.

product.title: A Day in Pompeii
product.description:
The Roman city of Pompeii was destroyed by the eruption of Mount Vesuvius in AD 79, and ultimately vanished beneath thick layers of volcanic ash. Virtually untouched for over 1,700 years, the city and the remains of its inhabitants were sealed in a time capsule—a lost civilization and one of the greatest archaeological treasures ever unearthed. Pompeii’s rediscovery – building by building, street by street, block by block –provided historians a rare look at an ancient Roman townscape unchanged over the centuries.
Now Museum of Science visitors can experience the life and death of this ancient Roman city in the traveling exhibit A Day in Pompeii. For the first time ever in Boston, more than 250 artifacts—exceptional objects that lay buried in Pompeii's ruins, including room-size frescoes, marble and bronze sculptures, jewelry, gold coins, and everyday household items--are on display. All evoke the richness, culture, and bustle of daily life in the Roman Empire’s favorite vacation resort, situated near Italy’s beautiful Amalfi Coast. Visitors can also examine casts of the volcano's victims, frozen in their last moments, and discover the power of volcanoes past and present.
Pompeii is a once-in-a-lifetime experience giving visitors a chance to walk the streets and discover the treasures of a city steeped in legend and mystery.

product.title: Geckos: Tails & Toepads
product.description:
Geckos are among the most adaptable lizards–more than 1,000 species have conquered habitats from balmy tropical beaches and lush rainforests to frigid mountain slopes and parched deserts. They range from shadowy nighttime hunters with unbelievable camouflage to neon-colored nectar eaters that scamper around in daylight. Bulging eyes, night vision, ‘sticky’ toepads, squawking voices and disposable body parts–welcome to a gecko’s world!
Geckos are endowed with a charisma that marketing firms can’t resist and audiences can’t ignore. This exhibition introduces visitors to their remarkable diversity with bold backlighted graphics, engaging interactives and living examples from around the world. Lush, naturalistic habitats anchor the exhibit and draw audiences into the geckos’ realm. Visitors can experience gecko night vision, magnify gecko toepads, listen to gecko voices, activate video clips of geckos in action, try to spot camouflaged geckos and build a custom gecko for various environments.
Exhibit will include a minimum of 15 species of live geckos.

product.title: Tornado Alley - 2nd run
product.description: Return of Tornado Alley to coincide with Spring tornado season

product.title: Lost Egypt: Ancient Secrets, Modern Science
product.description:
This exhibit explores how modern archaeologists use science and technology to uncover and understand the people and culture of ancient Egypt through the use of 17 interactives & 60 real artifacts. The exhibit will be divided into the following 4 theme areas:
Orientation Entrance – A stylized Egyptian scene filled with life-size photos transports you to modern Egypt, where you view an orientation video, a floor map, and learn about some of the archaeologists working in Egypt today.
Field Site – Modeled after an archaeological field site in Egypt, this area encourages visitors to explore the tools, techniques, sciences and technologies used at the Lost City of the Pyramid Builders site on the Giza Plateau. Stories from the archaeologists focus on life in the filed, discoveries, artifacts and careers. Find a site, identify material remains, analyze findings, and engage in the process of scientific inquiry about the lives of the Pyramid Builders. Compare results to those of the experts working at the Giza Plateau.
Ancient Egyptian Culture – This themed area contains a human mummy, a theatrical presentation about the Egyptian beliefs in the afterlife, funerary artifacts and exhibits about the art and language of ancient Egypt.
Laboratory – Explore how modern science and technology helps us understand human mummies, animal mummies and artifacts from ancient Egypt. Come face-to-face with ancient Egyptians here in scans and forensic reconstructions.

product.title: Space Junk 3D
product.description: Soar 22,000 miles above Earth amid a junkyard of orbiting debris. Witness mind-boggling collisions, and learn what can be done about our growing problem of human-made space trash.

product.title: Flying Monsters 3D
product.description: Britain's best-known natural history film-maker, Sir David Attenborough highlights the evolution and variety of pterosaurs that took to the air while dinosaurs roamed the earth.

product.title: Pixar Prototyping
product.description: Adult Gallery - prototyping for Pixar Exhibit

product.title: Destination Station
product.description: NASA exhibit about the International Space Station

product.title: Journey Into Amazing Caves - 2nd run
product.description: Go underground. Wiggle through some passageways to discover the alien world beneath your feet. These amazing caves were formerly accessible only to experienced divers, cavers, and daredevils. Now it's time to see them for yourself!

product.title: Mammoths & Mastodons: Titans of the Ice Age
product.description:
From 1.8 million to 10,000 years ago, as an Ice Age cooled global temperatures, colossal mammals roamed Europe, Asia and North America. Standing up to 14 feet high at the shoulder, the mammoth migrated across the Bering Land Bridge into a new world of grasslands and predators, humans not least among them. Slightly shorter, more heavily built, and indigenous to North America, the mastodon also marked an imposing presence on the Pleistocene landscape. What was life like for these animals, whose remains invite so much modern fascination and speculation?
In The Field Museum's new traveling exhibition, explore the world of mammoths and mastodons through an exciting collection of skeletons, casts, tusks, preserved flesh, immersive media, and engaging interactives. Learn to tell the difference between a mammoth and a mastodon, and meet other amazing creatures from the Ice Age landscape such as the saber-toothed cat, giant sloth, and Dire Wolf. Be immersed in a richly animated Ice Age panorama as mammoths lumber toward you out of the forest at dawn; experience the cry of the osprey and hear and see skeins of geese flying overhead. Learn how Clovis point-armed hunters stalked these elephantine prey. Investigate why these incredible species died out, and whether it's possible to clone them today. From the Pleistocene to the present, watch evolution in action and explore the dynamic world of Mammoths and Mastodons: Titans of the Ice Age

product.title: The Honeybee: Revealed
product.description: Art and Science Gallery

product.title: One World, One Sky: Big Bird's Adventure
Design Zone
product.description: Temporary exhibit from OMSI (SMEC)

product.title: Ocean Stories: A Synergy of Art and Science
product.description: Art and Science Gallery

product.title: Dead Sea Scrolls: Life in Ancient Times
product.description: 600 artifacts and 20 scrolls (displayed in two batches of 10 for 3 months each) from the collection of Israel National Treasures in association with the Israel Antiquities Authority (surcharge exhibit)

product.title: Seasons of Change: Global Warming in Your Backyard
product.description: Stearns gallery

product.title: Climate Change in our World: Photos by Gary Braasch
product.description: Art and Science Gallery Ending date could be extended

product.title: Cool Globe
product.description: on outdoor plaza - One of several dozen art pieces around Boston, 27 on Boston Common, several on Esplanade

product.title: Santa vs. The Snowman
product.description: lighthearted animated holiday film

product.title: Explore: Wonders of the Winter Sky
Computer Education Week Activities
product.description: Proposed collaboration with Google to encourage public to learn computer science. Activities to be determined.

product.title: Our Global Kitchen
product.description: AMNH exhibit Dates confirmed

product.title: Innovation in the Art of Food: Chef Ferran Adrià
product.description: Member Preview Feb. 14th

product.title: Grand Canyon Adventure: River at Risk-2nd run
product.description: Historical and environmental look at Colorado River and its role in the past and present day water conservation story

product.title: Pandas: Long Journey Home
product.description: Search for scientific understanding of the habits and needs of Chinese Giant Pandas and how to use that information to successfully reintroduce animals back into their natural home environment.

product.title: 2theXtreme: MathAlive!
product.description: Sharing Nichols with Animals Without Passports and Grossology

product.title: Grossology
product.description: 2500 SF, sharing Nichols with MathAlive! and Animals Without Passports

product.title: Water Stories: Conversations in Paint and Sound
product.description: Artwork by Anne Neely. Located: Adult/Art & Science Gallery

product.title: Mystery of the Maya
product.description: SMM film examining the history, customs and life span of the Mayan culture

product.title: Galapagos
product.description: 1999 version from IMAX - excellent images and story line

product.title: The Photography of Modernist Cuisine
Maya: Hidden Worlds Revealed
product.description: Nichols Gallery. Collaboration between Science Museum of Minnesota, MOS, and DMNS

product.title: Road Salt: A 4500 Mile Journey
product.description: Art & Science Gallery. Winter 2015 only.

product.title: Spirit of the Marathon
product.description: 4 free-standing panels and an "archway", illustrating the history of the modern marathon from ancient Greece to today. Located in the rear lobby.

product.title: Airplanes: A World in Flight
product.description: Role of air travel as a cultural transformative technology

product.title: Dinosaurs Alive - 3rd run
product.description: '07 GSF production - discoveries in dino research from around the world - lots of CGI

product.title: Macro or Micro?
product.description: Photos from Salem State University research projects using satellite imagery and SEM images.

product.title: The Science Behind Pixar
product.description: MOS developed exhibit based on work of Pixar Animation Studios. SMEC exhibit will travel after MOS installation.

product.title: Arabia-2nd run
product.description: young Saudi filmmaker explores his own history and heritage as he uses his camera to examines the forces and natural environment that make his country what it is

product.title: MIT Robot Cheetah (end date tentative)
product.description: Single Case. Blue Wing, Level 1

product.title: Adrenaline Rush-week end run
product.description: Cliff jumping paragliding and test of Leonardo's parachute design in US desert

product.title: Jerusalem - 2nd run
product.description: Holy city to 3 major world religions told through perceptions of 3 young women, one representing each of those religions

product.title: Wild Africa
product.description: New BBC-GSF film with a focus on wildlife

product.title: Seasons of Change: Global Warming in Your Backyard
National Parks Adventure
product.description: Overview of US National Parks in their 100 anniversary year - spectacular views with young adventurers through-line

product.title: Animals: Machines in Motion
product.description: Member Preview 2/13/16, Public Opening 2/14/16. Exhibit developed by Field Museum, Chicago. This is also a return visit for T-Rex Sue that was seen here in 2000

product.title: What I Eat (End Date TBD)
product.description: This exhibit was last displayed at MOS in the Art & Science gallery in 2011

product.title: Dolphins -- 3rd Run
product.description: Researchers work with Dolphins in the open ocean to better understand intelligence and level of communications sophistication.

product.title: Treasured Lands: The US National Parks in Focus
product.description:
Located in the Art & Science gallery and in the Blue Wing
Images of each of the US National Parks, on display in honor of the US National Parks Centennial in August 2016

product.title: Frogs: A Chorus of Colors
product.description:
4/16: Member Preview 4/17: Public Opening
This popular live animal exhibit from Clyde Peeling Reptiland is returning for second showing.

product.title: Spiders: Alive!
product.description:
Opening date tentative
Member Preview 6/11, Public Opening 6/12 Exhibit from AMNH with 15 species of live spiders, and live presentations daily.

product.title: Defeating Disease (Infectious Diseases)
product.description:
End date tentative.
Exhibit located in HHL Gallery.

product.title: Da Vinci - The Genius
product.description: Nichols Gallery

product.title: Chocolate
product.description:
Stearns Hall, on loan from the Field Museum in Chicago.
Member Preview: 1/28 Public Opening: 1/29

product.title: Defeating Disease 2 (Infectious Diseases)
product.description: Reinstallation in HHL Gallery. Includes materials from AMNH-NYC exhibit about defeating diseases world-wide, plus historical material from Boston Children's Hospital, including circa 1950s Iron Lung. End date tentative.

product.title: POPnology
product.description: Previews yet to be schedule. Located in 2/3 of Nichols Gallery. This exhibit highlights how pop culture has inspired modern technology.

product.title: Many Faces of Our Mental Health
product.description: Located in the Art & Science Gallery

product.title: New England Caterpillars: Life on the Leaf Edge
product.description: Installed in half of Stearns Hall. Photography by Sam Jaffe of The Caterpillar Lab.

product.title: Gridiron Glory
product.description:
Member Preview 10/7 Public Open 10/8
From the Pro Football Hall of Fame, there is an interactive "training camp" section in addition to football memorabilia. MOS will likely augment with additional science content.

product.title: A Mirror Maze: Numbers in Nature
product.description: Nichols Gallery. Exhibit owned by MSI, Chicago. Member Preview 2/3/18, Public Open 2/4/18. Exhibit will close on Wednesday, 4/25.

product.title: Dora and Diego: Let's Explore!
product.description: On loan from The Children's Museum of Indianapolis. A&S Gallery (Blue Wing Level 2 gallery)

product.title: Crocs: Ancient Predators in a Modern World
product.description: Live animal exhibit from Clyde Peeling Reptiland

product.title: Space: An Out-of-Gravity Experience
product.description: 6/23 is Member Preview, 6/24 is Public open. In Nichols Gallery. SMEC exhibit from Science Museum of Minnesota.

product.title: All Aboard! Trains at Science Park
product.description: Member Preview on 11/17, Public Open on 11/18. Exhibit will be in Stearns, featuring a large model train display.

product.title: Nature's Superhero's: Life at the Limits
product.description: Nichols Gallery; on loan from AMNH. No Member Preview planned due to mid-week opening.

product.title: Wild Kratts: Ocean Adventure
product.description:
MOS will be the premier venue for this 1500 sqft children's exhibit from Minnesota Children's Museum.
https://mcm.org/minnesota-childrens-museum-and-wild-kratts-join-forces-again-to-create-an-ocean-adventure-exhibit/

product.title: Dogs! A Science Tail
product.description: Developed by California Science Center.
